abstract: There was a time, Khanukasion Nisanov remembers, when he looked at his son and saw only greatness.   An old, yellowing photograph transports Mr. Nisanov back to those spirited days, when 5-year-old Vitaly was just discovering his musical gift. After hearing a song played only once, Vitaly would sing it himself, note for note, entertaining his parents and friends. Even Mr. Nisanov's musician friends agreed that the child was charmed, and they predicted that he would become an important composer.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, Khanukasion Nisanov remembers, when he looked at his son and saw only greatness.

After recovery, she learned he had been born with a seizure disorder.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: IN his 61 years, Mr. F. managed to live through the Holocaust, adapt to life in a foreign country and survive two openheart operations.   And yet his greatest challenge, he says, is finding the strength to make a daily trek, one that often takes over an hour on the bus, from his subsidized apartment at Willet and Delancey Streets on the Lower East Side to his old neighborhood in the East Village. There he eats dinner at his favorite diner, plays cards with his Polish and Ukrainian friends, and retells stories of his life.   Mr. F. is dying. His doctors say his heart is too weak to withstand the trauma of another operation, one necessary to keep the blood flowing properly through his slumped, fivefoot frame. ''I can count my months left on hand. I just thank God I owe nobody nothing.''
lead_paragraph: IN his 61 years, Mr. F. managed to live through the Holocaust, adapt to life in a foreign country and survive two openheart operations.

abstract: Some nights, when her mother works late, Monique Terc wanders through their apartment and sings. As Monique, an eighth grader, cooks dinner and does her homework, she performs from a diverse repertory: French carols, Latin processionals, African lullabies. The clear notes echo through the rooms, and suddenly they do not seem so empty.   "It doesn't matter if I'm alone or in front of an audience," said Monique, who is 13. "Singing relaxes me and puts me in a good mood."
lead_paragraph: Some nights, when her mother works late, Monique Terc wanders through their apartment and sings. keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: THERE was no Thanksgiving turkey for the H family and the only Christmas cheer may be that the family will be able to keep a roof over its head.   The family lives in two rooms in a dilapidated tenement in Manhattan. Mrs. H sleeps on the couch in the living room, her 11-year-old son sleeps on the floor, and her two-week-old grandson sleeps between them in a crib. The baby's mother, 16, and the mother's sister, 13, share the small bedroom.   Crowded as these living quarters are, Mrs. H, 41, can barely afford them. Mr. H left the family years ago. Until last February, Mrs. H, who works as a stenographer, received supplemental assistance for her rent. But that aid, along wth her food stamps and Medicaid coverage, was terminated six months ago after Federal budget cuts. Mrs. H was told by her social worker that because she was employed, she was no longer eligible for such Government programs.
lead_paragraph: THERE was no Thanksgiving turkey for the H family and the only Christmas cheer may be that the family will be able to keep a roof over its head.

abstract: Confided to his studio apartment by illness, a former cabdriver compensates by bringing the outside world home.
snippet: Confided to his studio apartment by illness, a former cabdriver compensates by bringing the outside world home.
lead_paragraph: To a man who has chauffeured fares across the five boroughs, being confined to a studio apartment by diabetes, arthritis and heart disease must seem like a cruel irony. But Martin Rosenberg, a longtime Yorkville resident and former cabdriver, has compensated by bringing the outside world home, and it stares back from every available surface.

headline.main: A Shut-In Surrounded by Bits of the Outside World
headline.print_headline: A Shut-In Surrounded by Bits of the Outside World

keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Celeste Lawton was so occupied with her sick mother’s needs that she ended up leaving high school. Now she’s working hard to provide for her own daughter.
snippet: Celeste Lawton was so occupied with her sick mother’s needs that she ended up leaving high school. Now she’s working hard to provide for her own daughter.
lead_paragraph: At 13, Celeste Lawton was sticking needles in her mother’s arms: Melody Banks needed insulin injections to combat her diabetes, and there was no one else to help when the nurse was off duty.

headline.main: A Selfless Caretaker, First as a Daughter, Now as a Mother
headline.print_headline: A Selfless Caretaker, First for Her Mother, and Now as a Mother Herself

abstract: A grant from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund allowed 59 seniors on the Lower East Side continued access to an emergency alarm response system at an affordable rate.
snippet: A grant from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund allowed 59 seniors on the Lower East Side continued access to an emergency alarm response system at an affordable rate.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when Angelo Boccino did not mind falling — if it was from an airplane and he had a parachute. In fact, Mr. Boccino jumped out of planes on combat missions when he was an Army paratrooper in World War II, he said. Today, he is 93, and falling can be hazardous to his health. So Mr. Boccino, who uses a wheelchair, an electric scooter and a walker to get around, depends on an emergency alert bracelet he wears on his left wrist.

headline.main: With Small Devices, Older New Yorkers Gain Independence and Peace of Mind
headline.print_headline: With Small Devices, Older New Yorkers Gain Independence and Peace of Mind

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: She had a baby girl last summer, but J. Sellers felt no joy. She was just 22, recovering from an anguished childhood and finding that maturity brought its own misery.   "I didn't want to see her or hold her," she said of the infant. "I was all wrapped up in my problems, and I couldn't think about anything else."
lead_paragraph: She had a baby girl last summer, but J. Sellers felt no joy. She was just 22, recovering from an anguished childhood and finding that maturity brought its own misery.

abstract: A woman who met tragedy after tragedy began the hard work of rebuilding her life after a neighbor’s observation and a phone call.
snippet: A woman who met tragedy after tragedy began the hard work of rebuilding her life after a neighbor’s observation and a phone call.
lead_paragraph: Diana Martin says she has lived through so much drama that she could write a book. Themes would include abandonment, loss of a son, the murder of her one true love and perseverance through years of difficulty.

abstract: Two health scares, her own and her grandmother’s, sidelined Zoe Morris. Now she’s searching for a job, an integral part of feeling whole again.
snippet: Two health scares, her own and her grandmother’s, sidelined Zoe Morris. Now she’s searching for a job, an integral part of feeling whole again.
lead_paragraph: Several months after a debilitating stroke nearly 30 years ago, Zoe Morris ventured outside for the first time. The sidewalks were teeming with impatient pedestrians, and Ms. Morris suddenly found New York City’s familiar streets overwhelming.

abstract: After losing both parents to illnesses in recent years and fighting off an aggressive form of testicular cancer, Michael Mercado is focusing on his future.
snippet: After losing both parents to illnesses in recent years and fighting off an aggressive form of testicular cancer, Michael Mercado is focusing on his future.
lead_paragraph: Michael Mercado, 20, has made a bargain with fate. He would finish school and find a good job working on cars if only, he says, “the cancer stays away.”

abstract: Sydney Almorales deferred his future after high school to tend to his dying stepfather, and then could not afford the subway trip to technology classes.
snippet: Sydney Almorales deferred his future after high school to tend to his dying stepfather, and then could not afford the subway trip to technology classes.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Sydney Almorales was wrapping up his senior year at Brownsville Academy High School, plotting his course to college. But by the middle of the year, his future as a student was abruptly overtaken by a more immediate duty: caretaker.

abstract: With papers fanned out on his lap and a pencil tucked behind one ear, Suresh Jaikaran described his latest work in progress, a 26-page research paper on the Persian Gulf war, as if it were the thorniest problem ever to face a 16-year-old.   "It has to have covers and an index and everything has to be perfect, just like a book," he said. "It's for social studies class."
